header_summary:
Antoine Poinsot clarifies a critical aspect of multiparty transaction protocols in Bitcoin, emphasizing that non-standard inputs are not considered attacks but rather an inherent part of the system's trustless nature, highlighting the balance between security and functionality in cryptocurrency systems. This discussion also addresses a new limit for transactions involving legacy script inputs to mitigate potential issues, demonstrating the ongoing adjustments to Bitcoin's protocol to maintain network robustness ([source](https://gnusha.org/pi/bitcoindev/49dyqqkf5NqGlGdinp6SELIoxzE_ONh3UIj6-EB8S804Id5yROq-b1uGK8DUru66eIlWuhb5R3nhRRutwuYjemiuOOBS2FQ4KWDnEh0wLuA=@protonmail.com/T/#m6bb53227b0fc33fe8e3f962df7f8ca6143c258d6)).

Conduition raises concerns about the practicality of integrating the WebAuthn standard with Bitcoin, due to its potential incompatibility with key features like deterministic backup seeds and hierarchical deterministic wallets, alongside the challenges of adapting it for decentralized systems prioritizing user autonomy. This discussion extends to the feasibility and timing of integrating new signature algorithms into the Bitcoin protocol, juxtaposed against the rapid advancements in post-quantum cryptography, suggesting a strategic reevaluation of development priorities within the community ([source](https://gnusha.org/pi/bitcoindev/GVA2lG8TET5qUPOU8JlHttBNLbTskqr_dbhzK9aOe_ZsPsNDyk2kWIPwmx3ngTchlGrsAIpubrVl24qmyqVgBvrZ8FT0POeomam2qB6-cqk=@proton.me/T/#mb4648d11e6487def3a9204054abf8fe08f23543a)).

Tim Ruffing's analysis of the post-quantum security of Bitcoin's Taproot as a commitment scheme offers reassurance against the threat of quantum computing to script-path spending, outlining a potential two-phase softfork upgrade path for integrating post-quantum signatures. This research provides a significant foundation for future-proofing Bitcoin against quantum attacks and emphasizes the current security adequacy based on SHA256's resilience ([source](https://eprint.iacr.org/2025/1307)).

A novel proposal by davidtaubmann aims to combat money centralization in Bitcoin by limiting wallet creation to one per individual, verified through national identity numbers or biometrics, suggesting a radical shift towards a more equitable distribution of wealth within the cryptocurrency ecosystem. This approach, however, challenges the anonymity and decentralization principles traditionally associated with Bitcoin, proposing a significant paradigm shift towards reducing inequality and corruption ([original post](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/issues/32897?reload=1?reload=1)).

recent_posts.title: Make pathological transactions with more than 2500 legacy signature operations non-standard
recent_posts.summary:
- Antoine clarifies a misunderstanding in Bitcoin multiparty transaction protocols.
- He differentiates between non-standard and attack inputs, emphasizing inherent trust issues.
- His explanation aids in understanding recent adjustments and their rationale in the protocol.

recent_posts.title: Revisiting secp256r1 signatures (i.e. P256, mobile HSM support)
recent_posts.summary:
- Integrating P256 into Bitcoin involves multi-year efforts and may be overtaken by newer technologies.
- The email suggests aligning WebAuthn's signature formats with Bitcoin to ensure future security compatibility.
- Concerns are raised about WebAuthn's limitations in preserving Bitcoin's user autonomy and security features.

recent_posts.title: Taproot is post-quantum secure when restricted to script-path spends
recent_posts.summary:
- A study finds Bitcoin's Taproot secure against quantum attacks, utilizing the quantum random oracle model.
- It suggests a two-phase softfork for Bitcoin, enhancing post-quantum security before quantum computing advances.
- Quantum computing currently poses less of a threat to Bitcoin than advancements in classical computing techniques.

recent_posts.title: Bitcoin Version 2 only for conscious living individuals
recent_posts.summary:
- The new Bitcoin fork proposes one wallet per person, verified by national identity numbers.
- It aims to limit institutional Bitcoin power, promoting financial democratization and global equity.
- Alternatives for countries without a national ID include biometric identification or other community-developed methods.

recent_posts.title: New paper on Proof of Usable Work
recent_posts.summary:
- A new paper presents a method to use global computational resources for "merge mining" a blockchain coin.
- This method, which measures computing effort in FLOPs, offers a more efficient, secure Proof of Work consensus.
- It proposes aligning coin issuance with the amount of FLOPs contributed, challenging Bitcoin's fixed supply model.

recent_posts.title: Where does the 33.33% threshold for selfish mining come from?
recent_posts.summary:
- Accurate timestamping in blockchain is vital for operations and preventing selfish mining.
- Nodes adjust clocks using the most-work chain to maintain blockchain integrity.
- Innovative decentralization includes using astronomical observations for time calibration.

active_posts.title: A Post Quantum Migration Proposal
active_posts.summary:
- The proposal focuses on transitioning Bitcoin to quantum-resistant cryptography to improve security.
- It outlines a phased migration to new cryptographic standards and decommissioning old ones.
- The initiative emphasizes global stakeholder cooperation to preemptively counter quantum threats.

active_posts.title: Human meaningful witness versioning
active_posts.summary:
- Ava Chow proposes mnemonic-based Witness Version allocation for Bitcoin, enhancing user safety.
- The proposal aims to replace numerical sequencing with mnemonic significance for address identification.
- This change seeks to improve clarity and security in recognizing transaction types within the Bitcoin ecosystem.

active_posts.title: [BIP Proposal] Proof-of-Activity Reclamation (PoAR)
active_posts.summary:
- Donald Dienst proposes a new Bitcoin protocol, "Proof-of-Activity Reclamation."- The proposal focuses on recycling inactive bitcoins to maintain mining incentives.
- Feedback is sought on the GitHub-hosted document to refine the development.

active_posts.title: Changes to BIP-360 - Pay to Quantum Resistant Hash (P2QRH)
active_posts.summary:
- BIP-360 modifications enhance Bitcoin's defense against quantum threats by introducing P2QRH.
- The proposal eliminates quantum-vulnerable key-spend pathways, increasing security.
- It outlines a forward-looking strategy for Post-Quantum signatures, promoting independent development.

active_posts.title: Exploring Extended Relative Timelocks
active_posts.summary:
- Bitcoin's 65535-block limit discussion sparks curiosity for ~10-year timelocks.
- Proposed method uses bit 21 in `nSequence` for 8x longer timelock durations.
- Experiment includes a tool for testing, sparking debate on use cases and risks.

active_posts.title: Fee-Based Spam Prevention For Lightning
active_posts.summary:
- Jager and Teinturier proposed Upfront and Time-Dependent Reverse Hold Fees for LN efficiency.
- Enhancements include payment confirmation secrets and burn outputs to secure fee allocation.
- Advanced protocols introduce three fee types and innovative fee collection methods to improve LN.

today_in_history_posts.title: Improving JoinMarket's resistance to sybil attacks using fidelity bonds
today_in_history_posts.summary:
- The debate focuses on if rented TXO fidelity bonds could heighten centralization and reduce privacy.
- Makers inclined towards profit may centralize coins, creating opportunities for de-anonymization by attackers.
- Despite possible centralization, the core goal remains enhancing privacy without compromising bitcoin's inherent properties.

today_in_history_posts.title: Trampoline Routing
today_in_history_posts.summary:
- Trampoline routing enables deferred route calculation in lightning networks via trampoline nodes.
- It involves Alice sending payments through trampoline nodes, using layered onions for route description.
- The system integrates fee and cltv requirements with existing gossip infrastructure for efficiency and reliability.

today_in_history_posts.title: Deflationary money is a Good Thing
today_in_history_posts.summary:
- Investment strategies are classified as passive or active, each involving different levels of engagement.
- The blog outlines passive investment's societal downsides, like asset underutilization and economic implications.
- It suggests central banks could stabilize economies by backing fiat currency with deflationary ones, like Bitcoin.
